alert.note: Alert for Giles (Virginia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 30 at 12:19AM EDT by NWS Blacksburg
info.description: .Heavy rainfall, which occurred during the past 24-36 hours continues to result in excessive runoff into area creeks, streams, and rivers. Minor to moderate flooding is ongoing in parts of Giles county, including along Wolf Creek, Walker Creek, and the New River in Narrows. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 615 AM EDT THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive runoff from earlier heavy rainfall is ongoing now. * WHERE...A portion of southwest Virginia, including the following county, Giles. * WHEN...Until 615 AM EDT Tuesday. * IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1213 AM EDT, local law enforcement reported flooding at the RV campgrounds along the New River and U.S. 460 in Narrows. In addition, Walker Creek at Bane remains in flood at 12 ft. Flood stage is 11 ft. Minor to moderate flooding continues along creeks, streams, and rivers throughout the county, especially the western areas such as Pearisburg, Narrows, Rich Creek, and Glenn Lyn. - It is particularly difficult to determine the degree of flooding at night. When in doubt, stay out! Do not drive into areas where water covers the road. Stay away from creeks, streams, rivers, and other drainage areas. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Pearisburg, Narrows, Pembroke, Peterstown, Poplar Hill, Rich Creek and Glen Lyn. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks. When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of flooding, including mudslides or flooded roads, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and on Twitter.
